thread.title: Camden Hills blanks Erskine Academy to end three-game slide
thread.title_full: Camden Hills blanks Erskine Academy to end three-game slide

author: news@courierpublicationsllc.com (Staff)
title: Camden Hills blanks Erskine Academy to end three-game slide
text:
View More... 
Rockport â€” As far as the Camden Hills field hockey team is concerned, the Windjammers have had the wind taken from their sails of late, having lost three straight games heading into their Saturday, Oct. 10 contest against visiting Erskine Academy of South China. 
And the Windjammers, playing in front of a larger crowd due, in part, to the school's homecoming festivities, did not disappoint fans in the least as the squad sailed to a 2-0 shutout win over the Eagles. 
A link to more photos from this game will appear later with this story. 
Camden Hills banged the back of the cage in both halves, with the scores coming off the stick of senior forward Hilary Merrifield. 
Merrifield got the offense going when she scored the game's first goal with 17:04 left in the first half, and added a second less than two minutes into the second half. 
Camden Hills' Willow Grinnell streaked down the right sideline and fired a mighty cross into the scoring area and onto the stick of Merrifield. 
Merrifield drew the goalie out from the cage and made a sharp move to her right before firing home a pivotal insurance goal with 28:18 left in regulation. 
The Windjammers held a 5-2 lead in shots and a 10-2 advantage in penalty corners. 
Jenna Stearns made two saves in the cage for Camden Hills, while Hannah Burns made three saves in goal for Erskine Academy. 
Gardiner 1, Camden Hills 0 
At Gardiner Oct. 6, the Windjammers stood toe-to-toe with the Tigers for much of the game, but the hosts got a goal from Sarah Morgan with 4:49 to go in regulation, which proved the difference in the game. The squads were scoreless at halftime. 
Jenna Stearns made four saves in the cage for Camden Hills, while Kaylin Mansir made one save in goal for Gardiner. The Tigers held a 5-1 lead in shots and a 7-3 edge in penalty corners. 
In the Maine Principals' Association Heal Point Standings for Class B North, Camden Hills (7-6, 41.9388 points) is eighth, while Gardiner (11-2, 119.7959 points) is first in the 14-team region. The top 10 teams qualify for the playoffs.
